title: Uncle Tom's Cabin

cover.description: Title page first volume of 1852 Jewett and Co. edition
cover.alt: Title page with the text 'UNCLE TOM'S CABIN; or, LIFE AMONG THE LOWLY. By HARRIET BEECHER STOWE.'  Below that text is a drawing showing an outdoor cabin with a Black adult in the doorframe and three Black children outside. A man carrying a what appears to be a whip and approaching the people around the cabin is in the background.  Below the drawing is text saying 'VOL. I. BOSTON: JOHN P. JEWETT & COMPANY. CLEVELAND, OHIO, JEWETT, PROCTOR & WORTHINGTON. 1852.

overview: One of the best-selling novels of the 19th century, <cite>Uncle Tom's Cabin</cite> energized the abolitionist movement, and angered many slaveholders, by contrasting the cruelty and injustice of slavery with the saving power of Christianity.

incidents.description: Prior to the Civil War, many southern states outlawed the possesssion of abolitionist literature, particularly by African Americans. In 1857, {ln:https://harriettubmanbyway.org/rev-sam-greens-descendant-speak-oct-6/|Samuel Green}, a lay minister who had been freed from slavery in 1837, was arrested and charged with 'knowingly having in his possession a certain abolition pamphlet called Uncle Tomâ€™s Cabin, of an inflammatory character and calculated to create discontent amongst the colored population of this State.'  The Maryland law he was charged with violating carried a minimum jail sentence of 10 years, but Green was eventually freed in 1862 on the condition that he leave the state.
